George Orwell

The Appeal of the Dystopian Novel

    Timeline of George Orwell's life:

  • 1903 - Blair, Eric Arthur [pseud. George Orwell] was born in Motihari, Bengal, India.
  • 1911 - After returning with his parents to England, he was sent in 1911 to a preparatory boarding school on the Sussex coast. He was later to tell of the miseries of those years in his posthumously published autobiographical essay,Such, Such Were the Joys.
  • 1917 - 1921 - Won scholarships to two of England’s leading schools, Winchester and Eton, and chose the latter. It was there that he published his first writing in college periodicals.
  • 1922 - Went to Burma as assistant district superintendent in the Indian Imperial Police. Later he was to recount his experiences and his reactions to imperial rule in his novel Burmese Days and in two brilliant autobiographical sketches, “Shooting an Elephant” and “A Hanging,” classics of expository prose.
  • 1928 - Resigned from the imperial police. After this he choose to immerse himself in the life of the poor and outcast people of Europe.
  • 1933 - Publishes Down and Out in Paris and London, where he recounted in fictional form his experiences among the poor.
  • 1934 - Publishes his first novel, Burmese Days.
  • 1935 - Publishes A Clergyman’s Daughter.
  • 1936 - Publishes Keep the Aspidistra Flying.
  • 1937 - Publishes The Road to Wigan Pier, his first socialist book, an original and unorthodox political treatise, where he combines mordant reporting with a tone of generous anger that was to characterize Orwell’s subsequent writing.
  • 1938 - Writes Homage to Catalonia, a vivid account of his experience during the Spanish Civil War.
  • 1939 - In his next novel, Coming Up for Air, he shows a paradoxically conservative strain.
  • 1941 - 1943 - Works on propaganda for the BBC.
  • 1943 - Orwell becomes literary editor of the Tribune, a left-wing socialist paper.
  • 1944 - Orwell finishes Animal Farm, a political fable based on the story of the Russian Revolution and its betrayal by Joseph Stalin. At first Orwell had difficulty finding a publisher for the small masterpiece, but when it appeared in 1945, Animal Farm made him famous and, for the first time, prosperous.
  • 1949 - Publishes his last book, Nineteen Eighty-four, a novel he wrote as a warning after years of brooding on the twin menaces of Nazism and Stalinism. The novel is set in an imaginary future in which the world is dominated by three perpetually warring totalitarian police states.
  • 1950 - Dies from tuberculosis in a London hospital.

  • (information retrieved from Encyclopædia Britannica, access date: Julho 20, 2018)

What Orwell's experiences – both as figure of authority and as scullion – had given him was a lived understanding of the human condition. It was this grounding in reality that bestowed a more profound political instinct than would be available to some sloganeering zealot. He had acquired a capacity to empathise with the foot-soldiers of history, the put-upon people generally taken for granted, ignored or squashed by the great isms of one sort or another. It conferred upon him the remarkable ability to achieve what every journalist and essayist seeks.
He could tell the truth.

― Jeremy Paxman, The Telegraph
